question: Should startups adopt a fully remote work model by default?

responses.text: Startups can benefit from remote work because hiring becomes global. It often reduces office costs. However, early-stage teams may struggle with alignment without strong process. A hybrid approach is usually safer than fully remote in the first year.

Remote-first helps startups recruit talent regardless of location and can improve employee flexibility. But full remote can hurt spontaneous collaboration and onboarding quality. For many seed-stage companies, hybrid is the practical default.

A fully remote model can lower burn rate and expand hiring. With disciplined documentation, teams can stay aligned remotely. Still, new startups should not assume fully remote always works; team cohesion may improve with periodic in-person collaboration.
